title: Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks: Current Conditions
body: Explore This Park    Plan Your Visit     Basic Information     Current Conditions              Alerts & Conditions         Alerts    Information        Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks Institute Stage 2 Fire Restrictions  Alert 1 , Severity ,information ,, Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks Institute Stage 2 Fire Restrictions  The parks are currently in Stage 2 fire restrictions due to dry conditions. Campfires are restricted in some campgrounds and picnic areas. more             Summer Traffic Congestion Record numbers of vehicles have entered these parks recently. In summer, on Fridays, Saturdays, and holidays from Memorial Day to Labor Day, long lines of cars have extended from the entrance stations. On a few of the busiest days, cars have waited over an hour to get through. Parking in some areas has also become crowded. If you plan to visit this summer, learn how to minimize your wait times as you enter the park and find parking once you're here.       Weather Weather can be very different between different park areas, and it can change quickly. Temperatures can vary 20 to 30 degrees as you change elevation. Icy or snowy roads requiring tire chains can occur anytime from early fall through early summer. There may be spring flowers in the foothills and snow in the Giant Forest at the same time. Be prepared to enjoy these parks safely. Before leaving home, check weather forecasts.   The Foothills- The lower elevations of Sequoia National Park, up to about 4,000 feet in elevation.   Giant Forest & Lodgepole- Forests of sequoias and other conifers in Sequoia, between about 5,000 and 7,000 feet in elevation.   Grant Grove- Forests of sequoias and other conifers in Kings Canyon National Park, between about 6,000 and 7,000 feet in elevation. A weather station there gives updates every five minutes.   Cedar Grove- On the floor of the Kings Canyon between about 3,500 and 4,700 feet in elevation, this area closes mid-November to mid-April.   Mineral King Valley- The narrow side road to this part of Sequoia National Park ends at about 7,800 feet in elevation, and closes late October through late May.   Check park road conditions, especially if you are coming between early fall and early summer. Check to see what destinations will be open when you get here, including roads, campgrounds, trails, and other facilities. A number of areas close from fall into spring. You may encounter wintry conditions, especially at higher elevations. Learn about tire chain requirements and other winter conditions. No matter what time of year you visit, please travel safely.          Seasonal Information  Current road conditions Campground information Current trail conditions See page 8 and 9 of the Visitor Guide for facility hours. Current fire information and current fire restrictions Rivers are dangerous year-round         Tire Chains and Winter Driving Snow and ice may be on park roads any time from early fall through late spring. It varies from year to year, but it's important to be prepared. Due to constantly changing conditions, please call 559-565-3341 (press 1, 1) for current, 24-hour road status and advisories. Before you visit, check our winter driving information, which includes a list of locations near park entrances where tire chains can be rented or purchased.
